author: randomishwalk
content:
Perhaps yet another dumber question than the one first asked by <@427013411004612618> — why is MEV a problem at all? Is MEV that much of a deadweight loss to the system vs being a source of revenue capture to allow block proposers to operate profitably, thereby being part of the “necessary” security budget of ethereum?

To use the “ethereum is a nation-state” analogy, I’d rather have a well-funded defense budget that is deployed in the best interests of the commonwealth but have a little bit of “corruption” than a squeaky clean one that is ineffective and would need to be funded with seigniorage

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content:
One issue is that capturing MEV creates negative externalities / degrades throughput, and another is that MEV can lead to consensus instability (reorgs at a minimum degrade UX of accepting payments, and be even nastier). 

Consider a humble sandwich attack: a single Uniswap tx that consumes about 105,000 gas leads to another transaction on either side. Now there's 315,000 gas consumed for the utility of a single person swapping, at the expense of the primary swapper.

(there are 'triple stacked sandwiches' with three 'authentic' tx with the two MEV-capture tx (the bread) on either side, but these are far rarer than the single-stacked, humble sandwich).

author: randomishwalk
content:
Thanks that’s helpful. Yeah agree sandwich attacks / MEV in general seems to be a “non-productive” use of gas (could make a similar claim in tradfi about usage of bandwidth for HFT / algo hedge funds which is probably the right analogy here). 

That said, it seems like explicitly tagged “MEV bots” actually account for a very small portion of gas used per this: https://ultrasound.money/

I wonder if anyone has done a study / crunched the data on how much more incremental slippage MEV causes on DEXs or how much of the total gas usage around DeFi-specifically (not sure how MEV works in the context of NFTs for example?) comes from productive activities vs MEV
